moves.2... d5 3. exd5 cxd5 4. d4: White now has a hole on e4.
moves.4... Bf5 5. Nf3 Nf6 6. Bd3 Qd7 7. O-O Nc: This exchange is advantageous for Black. White's e5 knight was better than Black's c6 knight.
moves.10... bxc6 11. Qc2 e6: If White exchanges bishops now, Black gets an open g-file for attack.
moves.12. Nd2 Bd6 13. Nf3: White moves his other knight to e5.
moves.13... Ne4: Unfortunately for white, the knight won't be able to remain on e5.
moves.14. Ne5 f6 15. Nf3 h6: Black does not fear Nh4. Simply Rg8 gives Black a strong attack if White decides to exchange knight for bishop.
moves.16. Be3 g5: All of Black's minor pieces are "bad."
moves.17. fxg5 hxg5 18. Bxe4 dxe4: White exchanges but blundered in the process.
moves.19. Nxg5: White gets no compensation for this sacrifice.
moves.21. Kf2 Qc7 22. Ke2 Qg3 23. Bf4: A blunder. The position was untenable for White anyways.
moves.23... Qxg2+ 24. Rf2 Qg4+ 25. Ke3 Rh3+: White is losing huge material here.
moves.26. Kd2 Bxf4+ 27. Rxf4: White sacs the exchange to avoid losing his queen. Here, White resigned. Note how Black's king has always been on e8.
